title: beyond smoke mirrors brexit deal remains likely
story: Will this be the week when the shape of Brexit is finally settled? Yes, if the UK and the EU can agree their future relationship, to enter into force from the end of the “transition period” on January 1, in a way that is legally clean.Yet difficulties persist in three main areas: First of all, fisheries. Secondly, the EU’s demand for the UK to accept a level-playing-field, a regulatory 'straitjacket', in return for a degree of tariff-free market access. Thirdly, the question of how to police the terms of the deal - “governance”. On top of that, a deal is also needed on the implementation of the Northern Irish aspects of the Withdrawal Agreement, which entered into force earlier this year.Irish foreign minister Simon Coveney has stated that he is more optimistic now about progress made by the so-called EU-UK Joint Committee here. This follows rumours that the UK would be prepared to drop elements of the UK Internal Market and Finance Bills, which the EU sees as violating the terms of the orce deal, if a free trade deal is concluded.As always with these kinds of high-stakes negotiations, everything is linked to everything else. When it comes to fisheries, there has reportedly been progress over the past week, but no deal yet, despite some briefings to that effect on Sunday. France has now accepted that the EU will suffer reduced access to British waters. There is also now more awareness in the British side that a no-deal would badly damage the fishing industry, particularly in Scotland, as the UK relies heavily on being able to sell its fish to EU customers.The EU is thought to be asking for 10 years of unfettered access to British waters while the UK is offering the EU 3 years of 'status quo' on access to certain fisheries. Even if both sides somehow met in the middle, concessions here will in any case be linked to concessions on the other sticking points.The level playing field sticking point very much relates to the heart of the changes Brexit will bring about: to what extent will the United Kingdom still need to take EU regulation into account in exchange for a degree of EU market access? In the EU’s ideal world, the United Kingdom would receive full market access, in return for taking over all of the EU’s relevant regulations, as Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein do.Given that this is a no-go, the EU now aims to impose some kind of level playing field in return for a so far unknown degree of market access. Interestingly, Stefaan de Rynck, an adviser to Michel Barnier has stressed that there is a “huge difference” between 'no-deal' and a deal, especially for certain sectors like the car industry and agriculture. In my opinion, this means that UK-based manufacturing is likely to continue to enjoy a large degree of market access.For car manufacturers, but also the chemicals and aerospace industries, it is important that UK regulations covering products manufactured in the UK are recognised as “equivalent” by the EU, so these products can enter the EU, even if no tariffs were levied on them, something which seems likely, even with a degree of customs bureaucracy.Equally, for EU food or textile producers, it’s vital that the UK accepts EU standards of production, even given the absence of tariffs. Switzerland enjoys proper EU market access for manufacturing, but not for financial services, and this is in line with Switzerland taking over most EU rules for the former sector but not for the latter.A likely compromise between the EU and the UK could involve the EU agreeing to water down the scope of its “Level Playing Field”, meaning that the UK would accept a concessions, mainly on state aid, but not so much on environmental and social standards, which are typically quite uncompetitive in the EU.In return, the UK would probably give some way on the core Brexit question: “governance”. This concerns the degree to which the promises made by the UK can be legally enforced: through an arbiter, or not? With a means for the EU to punish the UK by restricting market access if it violates the terms agreed? Through a unilateral EU decision or not? Those questions are of prime importance for the EU, and to the extent there will be points of EU law to be interpreted –  the EU is legally required to demand that only its own top Court - the European Court of Justice – is able to settle those questions.In a nutshell, as long as the EU agrees to a watered down level-playing-field and the UK to a binding way to enforce this, a deal will be agreed. Given the high stakes, with Covid continuing to plague the economies on both sides of the Channel, one would expect both sides to make an extra effort to avoid the damaging effects of a 'no-deal' outcome. That this would not be a rosy prospect for Britain, which would suddenly risk tariffs on half of its trade, has been widely accepted, but also for EU member states, it would mean massive economic damage at a most unwelcome time.Germany would face a cost of 8.2 billion euros in annual exports, thousands of fishing jobs are at stake in the coastal member states and Ireland could potentially face even more damage than the UK itself, while it may even face extra checks on its exports to other EU countries, in the absence of a Northern Irish border.Perhaps even more troubling than all the economic damage is that diplomatic ties would be hurt, at a time when the EU is witnessing ever greater political tensions between East and West, North and South. With all that in mind, EU leaders and especially Prime Minister Boris Johnson are likely to prefer to push through and seal a deal.Pieter Cleppe is a Brussels-based research fellow of the Property Rights AllianceMore from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: christmas bubble window should include travel days stop road
story: The Christmas-bubble window should be extended to include 'travel days' to prevent chaos on the roads and railways, a campaign group has urged.The Campaign for Better Transport group has warned the current guidance, which says people have to do all their travelling within the five days from December 23 to 27, punishes those making longer journeys to see loved ones.The group called for the two extra travel days people travelling to Northern Ireland are allowed on December 22 and 28 to be extended to those also travelling long distances across Britain.The call comes as passenger groups have been warning the narrow Christmas bubble window could cause chaos as millions travel en masse to see family for the five days ion which three households are able to mix.December 27 has been highlighted as a particular potential bottleneck, as train passengers have one day to travel home due to there being no services on Christmas Day and hardly any on Boxing Day.There is also set to be further disruption on December 27 as traditional engineering works begin on Christmas Day that will see King's Cross station closed and services limited from Waterloo until the new year.Paul Tuohy, chief executive of Campaign for Better Transport said: “People want to be able to see their friends and families at Christmas and we want them to be able to do so safely by public transport. “Currently, people will have to curtail their Christmas plans in order to get back before the window closes on December 27, especially those travelling long distances or on routes with engineering works. That’s why we need a wider travel window to allow people to make journeys safely and to avoid overcrowding on the public transport network. “Without adequate measures in place so that everyone who wants to travel by public transport can do so safely, we will see travel chaos and yet more cars on our already congested roads.”Last week, the Government announced a host of measures aimed at easing crowding and congestion on the transport network over Christmas, including additional train services and carriages on key days in the travel window.More than 770 miles of roadworks are being cleared to keep traffic moving, and the temporary speed limit where there are works on motorways is being raised from 50mph to 60mph.Ministers have also said they are in negotiations with the coach industry to make more services available over the Christmas period to take pressure off the rail network.Currently, Government guidance is that people can only travel outside the five-day bubble if they have ‘exceptional circumstances’.However, if they are travelling to Northern Ireland they are allowed to make their journeys on December 22 and 28, although they are not allowed to join their bubbles until December 23 and must have left them by December 27.Mr Tuohy said he welcomed the additional train services, but that he wanted the Northern Ireland travel days extended for longer journeys in the UK.He added: “Whilst we welcome the Government and rail industry's efforts to help people travel safely on public transport this Christmas, we are urging the Government to go further and adopt the Northern Ireland model of allowing travel one day either side of the Christmas-bubble window to help people making longer journeys. “Extra trains and extra carriages are very sensible, but people also need extra time to complete their journeys. A wider travel window would make it easier for more people to follow the guidelines this Christmas.”Meanwhile, analysis of train journey forecast data carried out for The  shows many people are planning to travel outside the Government’s recommended travel window.The data compiled by the company Zipabout, which advises the Government on overcrowding, showed in the four days leading up to the window trains will be five times busier than normal times.Likewise, the figures also showed rail services are likely to be more than twice as busy on the days immediately after December 27. The  has contacted the Government for comment. More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: ikea follows argos ditching catalogue 70 years
story: Ikea has followed Argos by announcing it will ditch its catalogue after 70 years.The Swedish flat-pack retailer first published the catalogue in 1951 but will wave it goodbye next year as “times are changing”. However, those who love browsing the beloved showrooms from home will be able to purchase a book instead.Ikea said its home furnishing advice and products will still continue to be available and it will continue to offer “full room inspiration” online. However, with more people using the internet it said it was “increasingly challenging” to reach shoppers through the catalogue. It said it has been testing new approaches for the past two years before making the final decision.Konrad Grüss, Managing Director at Inter IKEA Systems, said: “For both customers and co-workers, the IKEA Catalogue is a publication that brings a lot of emotions, memories and joy. “For 70 years it has been one of our most unique and iconic products, which has inspired billions of people across the world. “Turning the page on our beloved catalogue is in fact a natural process since media consumption and customer behaviours have changed. In order to reach and interact with many people, we will keep inspiring with our home furnishing solutions in new ways.”The details of the book are being finalised, but Ikea said it will “pay tribute to the final catalogue’s rich 70 year history, combining IKEA’s current view on life at home and its inspiring home furnishing solutions”.In July, Argos announced it would stop printing its famous “book of dreams”.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: national trust investigating mystery monolith isle wight beach
story: The National Trust launched an investigation after a mysterious monolith appeared on an Isle of Wight beach it owns without its permission.The appearance of the unexplained monument, reminiscent of something from a science fiction movie, follows similar sightings in the US and Romania which went viral on social media. The monolith appeared this weekend on Compton Beach, which is partly owned by the Trust, which said it was caught unawares by the bizarre development.A spokesman said: “We were unaware of the monolith’s presence until this morning, but we’ve now visited Compton Beach and it seems secure on a wooden plinth and is made from mirrored sections of plastic or perspex material.“We are still assessing it so we have no immediate plans to remove it, but of course we need to monitor over the next few days to ensure the beach remains safe and does not become overcrowded.”The Crown Estate, which owns the foreshore around the bay, is also investigating whether the monolith is on its land. The National Trust said its ranger believed the monolith was above the foreshore.The previous monoliths in America were claimed by an anonymous collective called The Most Famous Artist.When asked by the New York Times about the Isle of Wight monolith it stoked the mystery saying the monolith is “out of my control at this point”. It added: “Godspeed to all the aliens working hard around the globe to propagate the myth.”The National Trust said it had no idea who is responsible for the Isle of Wight installation. A spokesman added: “To prevent the risk of damaging important sites, we insist that anybody who wishes to put up something on our land must always contact us first.”It is roughly 7.5ft high and is wooden but covered with reflective plastic.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: prof steven pinker withdraws support eton teacher watching tendentious
story: A Harvard professor has withdrawn his support for a dismissed Eton teacher on the eve of his appeal hearing, it has emerged.Steven Pinker, the Johnstone Family professor of psychology at the Ivy League institution, admitted that he had not watched Will Knowland’s lecture when he initially wrote to Eton’s provost to champion his cause.On Monday night, Prof Pinker told The : “Only after watching the video later did I discover that his lecture went well beyond citing science and instead was a polemical and tendentious defense of masculine virtues.“Though I can imagine a pedagogical rationale for presenting and evaluating this controversial position in context, I can understand the College’s concern with the way the argument was presented.”Eton College has been engulfed by a free speech row after The  revealed that a Master was dismissed for gross misconduct after recording a lecture which questioned current radical feminist orthodoxy.The controversial lecture was part of the Perspectives course taken by sixth form students to encourage them to think critically about subjects of public debate.Mr Knowland (below) alleged that he was banned from delivering the lecture to pupils and then dismissed after he refused to remove a video of it from his personal YouTube channel.Eton has said the dismissal was not a matter of free speech but one of internal discipline.The £42,500-a-year school  has said it was left with no choice but to ask Mr Knowland to remove the video from the internet as it fell foul of equality laws.Prof Pinker was one of the first to declare his support for Mr Knowland, writing to Eton College’s provost last month saying: “In the name of honest and rigorous discussion of ideas, and respect for the ability of Eton students to evaluate and debate them, I urge you not to fire Mr Knowland.”But now Prof Pinker, an expert in experimental cognitive psychology, said that had he watched the video earlier he “wouldn’t have given the full support” to Mr Knowland that he indicated in his letter.“I don’t think that he should be fired necessarily,” he said. “But it seems that the College has every right to review the lecture and give him guidance. I think it is legitimate for them to say ‘No, it’s not OK to present that lecture’.“I do think that students should be exposed to controversial views. But the lecture I thought was not sound pedagogy and Eton was right to question it.”In another blow to Mr Knowland, the fashion tycoon and Old Etonian Johnnie Boden also withdrew his support. The 59-year-old founder of clothing retailer Boden had signed a petition which called for Mr Knowland’s reinstatement and accusing Eton of institutional bullying by firing him.Boden said at the time that he was extremely concerned about the incident adding: An institution I loved is losing its nerve.”But on Monday, he said that he too would like to retract his “unconditional support” for Mr Knowland, having now “watched the video and heard the arguments in more detail”.Boden said he has been assured that “lively debate of questionable views” are still very much encouraged at Eton but added “I can understand why the school cannot allow public posting of these views masquerading as facts. On Monday, a group of Old Etonians wrote to the school’s Head Master to say that Mr Knowland’s supporters have been “misleadingly” claiming that freedom of expression is at stake at the 580-year-old institution.“The reality is quite the opposite, as becomes apparent to those with common sense who watch Knowland’s lecture,” they said.“The school is defending the importance of substantiated debate in an educational setting that abides by professional and legal guidelines.”An internal panel, chaired by the school's vice-provost, will meet on Tuesday to consider Mr Knowland's appeal.If the panel upholds his dismissal, he said he is prepared to take the school to an employment tribunal and has so far crowdfunded close to £60,000 to cover potential legal costs.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: pubs encouraging drinkers purchase tickets live music nights
story: Pubs are encouraging drinkers to purchase tickets for their live music nights, in order to exploit a loophole which means customers do not have to order a 'substantial meal' when buying alcohol.In Tier 2 areas, live music venues are allowed to operate at 50 per cent capacity and serve alcohol to ticket holders at the bar, without them having to order a main meal as well.Now, a number of venues across the country are taking to social media to drum up support, telling customers not to “nurse half a lager all night” as they look to kickstart their businesses after a punishing second lockdown.“We will be ticketing Friday, Saturday, Sunday live music events for £3,” said The Horns in Watford, which is listed as a pub on companies house.“This also means we CAN SERVE YOU ALCOHOL WITHOUT FOOD at any of our weekends gigs,” they added.“Tickets will be sold on the door on a first come first serve basis.”New regulations brought in last week mean that the “table meal” clause does not apply “where alcohol is being provided to a customer at a cinema, theatre, concert hall or sports ground.” The alcohol must be “ordered by, and served to, a customer who has a ticket for an exhibition of a film, a performance or an event of training or competition at the venue, to consume in the area where the audience is seated to watch the exhibition, performance or event.”This has been a lifeline for small pubs which double up as live music venues.In South London the Cavern Freehouse wrote in a social media post: “We will be selling Tickets to get in on the door on the night. Doors open at 5pm, Bands start at 8pm and bar closes at 10pm. No food is now required.  “I would suggest people get here early as it will get full very quickly as I'm limited to 50 people. No bookings, it's a first come basis.  “If you are someone that nurses half a lager all night then I would please ask you not to come as I'm trying to survive here and that place could be taken by someone that understands that!”Sue Hathaway, who works at the venue clarified: “The Cavern is classified as a grassroots music venue, not a pub.”The guidelines originally stated that alcohol could only be served as part of a ‘substantial’ meal, but the Music Venue Trust argued that 92 per cent of grassroots music venues do not have the necessary facilities to provide this. The revised decision to allow alcohol sales, therefore, identifies the purchase of a ticket as equivalent to the purchase of a meal.Mark Davyd, CEO of Music Venue Trust, said he had worked hard with the government to make the case that the consumption of culture and the consumption of food should be treated equally.He added that he was “delighted” with the outcome.In Tier 3 areas, however, all indoor entertainment venues must remain closed.Not all pub landlords are happy with the new rules.“I’m all for live music venues being supported, but if alcohol is being singled out as a root cause of infection, then it should be subject to the same restrictions everywhere, whether it is a pub, theatre, music venue or supermarket,” said Laura Trotten, who operates the Crown in Rutland.“Until now I could see some sense in serving food in order to try and mitigate against the effects of alcohol on people’s ability to adhere to the regulations, but this just doesn’t make sense,” she told the Morning Advertiser.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: want christmas return classic festive pop
story: Elton or Mariah? East 17 or the Pogues? The Christmas song choice maketh the man. Forget King Wenceslas or the goings-on in Bethlehem, there is no faster route to festive feeling than late 20th-century Christmassy pop – something the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge clearly know, having enlisted Shakin’ Stevens to regale passengers at Euston on Sunday with his 1985 track. Snow-covered cheer aside, however, his performance of Merry Christmas Everyone exposed a hard truth: that Britain has been without a proper Number 1 festive cracker for more than a decade and a half.Arguably more culturally significant in 1994 than Tony Blair becoming Labour leader, Torvill and Dean winning the British ice dancing championship or the Nemesis opening at Alton Towers was the release of East 17’s Stay Another Day. The wintry ballad is best remembered for its music video, which features the four chaps in giant white parkas (plus questionable hatsgoatee configurations) gesticulating in a lightly agitated manner as snow falls.Forget that the band’s legacy now mostly centres around lead singer Brian Harvey running himself over in 2005 after eating too many baked potatoes the tinkle of those sleigh bells and doleful chord progressions still can, all these years later, make one come over all misty. It’s not an out-and-out tinsel-covered track, obviously – there’s nary a mention of the C-word – but it was the last time a song released at this time of year successfully inserted itself into the festive Number 1 oeuvre. “I Love Sausage Rolls” by LadBaby (yes, this is a real song) may have occupied the same slot in 2019 but in our hearts, and Christmas playlists? Not a chance.The one I wheel out each year remains reliably unchanged: it features the 12 purest pieces of holiday pop, of which Elton John’s Step into Christmas takes an obvious first place, with appearances from Wizzard and Slade, Mariah Carey, Band Aid, John Lennon and the Jackson 5. Plus (quasi-)honourable mentions for The Darkness and Leona Lewis, who released (non-Number 1 ranking) festive songs with all the sufficient cheese, jingle and cheer to make listening on loop as habitual as those endless dips inside the Quality Street tub.Depending on how many times in one day you can tolerate Noddy Holder asking whether you’re hanging up your stocking on the wall (loads) or Paul McCartney being quite smug about what a wonderful time he’s having (fewer), this year has curtailed – along with most things – the sort of charming December tradition of hearing these same songs every time you enter a shop, pub or cafe, and being unable to stop yourself from humming along.Festive pop is so small a pool, compared with the non-Christmassy kind, that being able to listen for decades to this same hour or so of variations on a limited theme (there’s really only so much to say about snowmen) without new contenders to displace them must count for something.The current UK top 10 chart tells the same story – of the three Christmas songs currently residing there the most modern is Mariah Carey’s 1994 All I Want for Christmas Is You (beaten to the top spot that year by  East 17).I’m not sure what was in the festive song-making water 16 years ago, but if there was ever a time to inspire a new wave of enduring, sleigh-bell-laced chart-toppers, 2020 must be it.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: national lottery minimum age rise
story: NewsNational Lottery minimum age to rise to  from October in crackdown on gambling loopholeThe Mirror revealed last month that the Government was planning to close the loophole alongside a wide-ranging review of gambling lawsmirrorShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  DEC NewsThe minimum age will go up next year " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMinisters are today announcing a crackdown on a “lottery loophole” which meant that under-s were still able to gamble.  A cross-party group of MPs has been campaigning to prevent the National Lottery “exploiting” vulnerable  and -year-olds.  They claimed that allowing youngsters to buy lottery tickets, scratch cards and play online games acted as a gateway to much harder forms of gambling.  The Mirror revealed last month that the Government was planning to close the loophole alongside a wide-ranging review of gambling laws.  It will now be illegal for any of the , shops which sell any National Lottery products to under-s to do so from October. There are plans for online sales to stop from April - although ministers faced calls to bring in both changes immediately.  Ministers are already looking at loot boxes in video games, which critics say can also lead to problem gambling for youngsters. Culture minister Nigel Huddleston said: “We’re committed to protecting young people from gambling related harm which is why we are raising the minimum age for the National Lottery.  “Patterns of play have changed since its inception, with a sht towards online games, and this change will help make sure the National Lottery, although already low-risk, is not a gateway to problem gambling.” As part of the wider review, also announced today, the Government will consider online stake limits, advertising and the powers of the Gambling Commission. It will look at what action customers can takethey feel operators have breached their responsibilities on, for example, protecting vulnerable gamblers.  The review will also cover how to keep children and young people safe from gambling-related harm. A call for evidence, launched in September, will close in March as ministers work out how to update the Gambling Act for the digital age.  The industry has evolved at breakneck speed over the last  years, from the era having a flutter at a high street bookie, casino, race-course or seaside pier.  Carolyn Harris, chair of the All Party Parliamentary Group on Gambling Related Harm, said: “I welcome the increase in the minimum age of play for the lottery to  but this change should happen immediately not in October . I hope this delay is not reflective of the Government’s wider attitude to national gambling reform.”

story: NewsopinionTheres something very fishy about Brexit, and the whole thing is starting to stinkUsing fish as a bargaining chip is a red herring from Tory sprats who dont want you to realise that fish can swim, says Fleet Street FoxmirrorShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsopinion" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAnd so this is Brexit, and what has Boris done Well, heaposs hanging safe delivery of the coronavirus vaccine, future car sales, holidays, and co-operation on terror on the least important part of the British economy, becausehe doesnapost the headbangers in his own party will batter him. But fishing, while itaposs worth comparatively little to the UK, is politically impossible to ignore. Itaposs emblematic of the entire Brexit argument - Britannia ruling the waves as a sovereign nation, evil Johnny Foreigner nicking our fish and chips, and a load of old pollocks pretending to be something theyaposre not.Because while Johnson and his Hard Brexit weirdos bang on about piracy on the high seas, theyaposre forgetting the uncomfortable fact that the British fishing industry is not particularly British. Most of the British fishing fleet is controlled by just five firms - pescatarian barons who send supertrawlers out to scrape the seas of all that might be edible. The fuel their ships use is heavily subsidised by the EU.Government statistics show % of the deckhands are foreign nationals, who are cheaper and, as of January , will need to apply for visas to do the work theyaposre underpaid for, or  do it in France.They mostly fish for mackerel, which has the most profits, and itaposs mostly all sold to Europe. And less than three-quarters of it is from UK waters. The rest comes from - gasp - foreign seas.But % less mackerel is landed than in , even though the quotas have been set higher than science advises, because the drive for cash means fish stocks are disappearing.Oh, and at least one of these barons donated to the Vote Leave campaign. He must be VERY clever.Johnson is tying himself in knots over an industry with , fishermen, not all of whom are British. By comparison, the collapse of Arcadia about which the government is doing nothing involves , jobs, the failure of Debenhams risks , jobs, and the UK car industry which will collapse in a No Deal Brexit involves , workers, directly and indirectly. And , as threatened, Britain turns down an EU agreement for the sake of those fishermenaposs right to not bump into les Francaises dans le mer, those same fishermen will be facing big EU tarfs on the mackerel which they will be less able to sell abroad, but which will suddenly turn up, nice and cheap, on our supermarket shelves next to the chorinated chicken. And donapost assume, for a moment, that they can merelyto fishing for cod, and weaposll all get cheaper fish and chips. About % of the cod we consume comes from the waters around Norway and Iceland. Neither are EU members, but both are in the European Economic Area, and allow our fleet into their waters under its rules. After Brexit, they both want to fish in our waters too. So no sharing our waters, no chip supper.  To sum up - we fish in other waters, rely on foreigners to fish in our own waters, sell and buy fish with European nations, and in protecting fishing rights, are only protecting the rights of about five major corporations, some of which are foreign-owned.Itaposs the perfect emblem of Brexit, in that youaposre being lied to in order to convince you to support a thing which is ultimately more damaging than the thing youaposve already got.And thereaposs no need for the lies, because thereaposs a good pro-Brexit argument for fishing. These fleets burn huge amounts of oil that, after Brexit, will need to be subsidised in a world that wants to be greener. Post-Brexit, the government could tie fuel subsidies to cleaner vessels, better wages, higher safety standards.Quotas set by the EU have, according to campaigners, been far too high compared to the scientic advice on keeping the seas well-stocked. After we leave, we could set better quotas in our own waters, trading access to them with other nations infor healthier numbers of fish.And we could also use the laws of the sea as a blueprint for how we should deal with Europe after Brexit - co-operation, mutual interest, a better environment, and an understanding that,the fish get to keep their freedom of movement, perhaps humans could remember that borders are optional, too.

Matthew Mason, , is alleged to have beaten Alex Rodda, , with a wrench in woods in Ashley, Cheshire, on December  last year. Opening the trial at Chester Crown Court on Monday, Ian Unsworth QC, prosecuting, said the case for the prosecution was that Matthew Mason took Alexander Rodda to the woods on the pretence of sexual activity and then murdered him in cold blood. He said the defendant, then , and Alex had known each other for some months before his death and enjoyed an intimate sexual relationship.  Mr Unsworth  said Alex, a pupil at Holmes Chapel High School, was struck with at least  heavy blows in the brutal and merciless attack in a remote wooded area near Ashley, not far from Bowdon in Cheshire. He added: Alex did not stand a chance. His le ended in those woods. His partially clothed abandoned young body was discovered by a team of refuse collectors the next morning.  He added: The case for the prosecution is that Matthew Mason took Alexander Rodda to the woods on the pretense of sexual activity and then murdered him in cold blood. Alex had threatened to reveal their relationship after finding out Mason had been dating a girl for two years, the jurors were told. Mr Unsworth said in November last year Alex contacted Masonaposs girlfriend of two years, Caitlyn Lancashire, to tell her the defendant was messaging him in a flirty way and had sent him an explicit photo and video. Mason denied the allegations to his girlfriend, the court heard, but began making payments to Alexaposs bank account at the same time.  Alex told a friend Mason was paying him for sex andhe stopped the payments he would report him to the police, Mr Unsworth said. The jury heard his friend told Alex it was akin to blackmail and wrong. By November  Mason, who lived with his family on a farm near Knutsford, had paid £, to Alex over a three-week period, following the alleged threat by his victim to reveal their relationship, the court was told. Mr Unsworth said: The messages that have been recovered show that, over time, the defendant was complaining that the payments were cleaning him out.  The court heard telematics data from a tracker, used for insurance purposes, had been used by police to follow the movements of Masonaposs Renault Clio at the time of Alexaposs death. Telephone and social media data had also been analysed although Alexaposs phone had not been recovered, Mr Unsworth said. He said: We suggest that the defendant disposed of that telephone and he has decided not to tell anyone where it is or where it went to. The jurors heard that phone evidence would play a part in the prosecution case. They were told some background about Alex and were shown an image of him with a phone on a screen in court.  The prosecutor told them: He had a wide circle of friends from his locality, his school and from his work helping out in a local public house before his death.” The prosecutor said Mason, who had a girlfriend at the time, worked as an apprentice mechanic and he had a black Renault Clio which will assume importance during the trial. He said: “The evidence suggests that Alex and the defendant had known each other for some months prior to Alex’s death.” The prosecutor said on November  Alex messaged the defendant’s girlfriend of some two years and askedshe was going out with the defendant. On confirming that she was, Alex stated that the defendant was trying to message him, the court was told.  The morning he contacted the defendant’s girlfriend Mason added ‘Alexander Rodda’ as a new payee on his bank account, the jurors were told. He paid £ into the schoolboy’s account the next day, the first of a series of payments totalling £, by November , the court was told. Alex told someone he knew the defendant was paying him for sex, said the prosecutor. They told him it was wrong and that Alex told themthe payments stopped he would report Mason to police, the jurors were told.  The QC said the person felt that this was akin to blackmail and told Alex that this was wrong. Alex told the person on at least five occasions that he had had sex with Mason, said the QC. The defendant had messaged Alex via Instagram and a relationship which began with a kiss developed into sex, the court was told. The jurors were told about an incident when Alex’s mother arrived home to find the teenager flustered and a strange man, the defendant, inside her home.

story: NewsDad-of-three took own le at Eden Project after being put at risk of losing his jobMarc Mappley, , was told his job in the horticulture science team at the tourist attraction in Cornwall was being put at risk of redundancy during the coronavirus pandemic in July this yearmirrorShareByKelly-Ann MillsChris Matthews:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsMarc Mappley was struggling to deal with his fathers death " %, rgba, rgba, url"Our free email newsletter sends you the biggest headlines from news, sport and showbizWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA dad-of-three who worked at the Eden Project took his own le after his job was put at risk of redundancy, an inquest has heard. Marc Antonio Dominguez Mappley, who worked in the horticulture science team, died at the attraction’s chemical storage area on July . An inquest into the -year-oldaposs death heard he suffered from a history of depression and had once before attempted to kill himself at the attraction several years prior. He was also struggling to deal with the death of his father when he died.The cause of Mr Mappley’s death was confirmed as hanging, Cornwall Live reports.Giving evidence during the hearing was Mr Mappley’s partner Jay Henwood, who described how they met on Match in . Ms Henwood said: “Marc had a great sense of humour and was a very, very funny guy. As time went on I learned he was a caring, loving person and an amazing father.” She claimed Mr Mappley told her he had previously attempted to kill himself, in the same place in  after his marriage ended, but wasn’t successful. But this was not reported to Eden HR or the police. Ms Henwood added “he found a new lease of le after as it scared him”. But in January Mr Mappley received the “shock” news that his father had died after a period of illness. He was said to have not properly addressed his grief. Worried about Covid and his finances, Mr Mappley and Ms Henwood moved in together in Tintagel with arrangements in place for him to see his children in Redruth. Ms Henwood described Mr Mappley as being “lacklustre and sleeping more” and making comments about being worthless and everyone being better off without him. In the months leading up to his death Mr Mappley was placed on furlough which created increased money worries and it was decided that he and Ms Henwood would together build her cleaning business. Mr Mappley’s position was also put under redundancy consultation although no final decision had been made. The couple had planned to marry as soon as possible but when Covid caused arrangements to be cancelled Mr Mappley was “hit hard”. Ms Henwood concluded by saying that although Mr Mappley had numerous worries, including planned alterations to when he could see his children, she was aware of no intention for him to take his le when he left for Eden that day. Mr Mappley’s ex-we and the mother of his children, Nancy, also gave evidence. She spoke of how they married in  but separated amicably when their marriage turned to a friendship. Ms Mappley said he had told her of his previous attempt to kill himself but he had promised never to do it again. She said: “He was a loving, kind and gentle person whereas Jay was fiery. He didn’t cope well with that. “His dad’s death hit him very hard as he had always been Marc’s rock.” On July , Mr Mappley sent his ex we a positive message saying he was “feeling strong” and three days later sent another one saying she is an amazing mum, they should be proud of their children and she would always have a place in his heart. She added: “He came to visit and told me he was being made redundant. His job was his identity and he loved it. He was clearly struggling but I didn’t think he was suicidal.” An Eden HR spokeswoman said Mr Mappley hadn’t actually been made redundant but the consultation was in process.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA veteran campaigner who will be one of the first people to receive a coronavirus vaccine on Tuesday says it is his “duty” to get the jab. Dr Hari Shukla CBE, , spoke out amid concerns over take-up. Staff worked through the weekend to get supplies to  hospital hubs around the country, and GPs have been put on standby to start delivering the vaccine from next week. Dr Shukla, a prominent race relations campaigner from Newcastle, will be vaccinated alongside his we Ranjan, , at the city’s Royal Infirmary on Tuesday morning. The grandad said: “I am delighted to be doing my bit by having the vaccine, I feel it is my duty to do so and do whatever I can to help.” The over-s and care home workers will get the first , doses, a week after the UK became the first country to approve the Pfizer jab. It cannot come soon enough as hospital bosses warned the NHS in England risks being overwhelmed in a third wave of infections after Christmas. The UK has secured  million doses of the Pfizer jab with around four million expected to be available this month. Those receiving a jab will be given an handwritten card with the vaccine name, date of immunisation and batch number. The cards will also act as a reminder for the second dose  days after the first. The first jab offers some level of protection around  days afterwards but the best protection comes a week after the second dose, officials have said. The Royal College of Nursing said identying patients likely to turn up for their second dose could be a “key challenge” in ensuring precious vaccine stocks are not wasted. The Pfizer jab was found % effective and reduced all cases of serious symptoms in clinical trials, with no signicant side effects. Doses must be stored at -C to keep them chemically stable and can only be moved four times before being used. Public Health England has  specialised Twin Guard ultra-low temperature freezers that can hold a total of five million doses, which are installed at hub hospitals. No date has yet been given for doeses to be brought to care home residents in England due to cold storage issues. Mass vaccination centres will be set up in sporting venues and conference centres when further supplies of vaccines become available in the new year. Defence Minister James Heappey confirmed Armed Forces personnel have been deployed to construct the centres.

story: NewsHeroic couple who fought to get dogmeat off the menu and devoted lives to helping straysEXCLUSIVE: Animal Hero award winners John and Gill Dalley helped ban the eating of dog and cat meat in Thailand and were a driving force behind the Soi Dog Foundation, tackling the problem of stray dogs and catsmirrorShareCommentsByRhian Lubin:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsJohn and Gill Dalley have won a Daily Mirror Animal Hero award " %, rgba, rgba, url"Our free email newsletter sends you the biggest headlines from news, sport and showbizWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWhen John Dalley held his dying we Gill in his arms one last time, he made a promise to her, vowing to carry on their work to improve the plight of cats and dogs in Thailand. Recalling the day Gill, who had lung cancer, died in hospital, John, , says: “I made a pledge not to close our doors to animals that needed us. “Gill was pumped with morphine but suddenly sat upright... and then she just died in my arms.” The couple had helped ban the eating of dog and cat meat in Thailand and were a driving force behind the Soi Dog Foundation, tackling the problem of stray dogs and cats. After Gill, , died in , John and his team carried on their mission to neuter and care for stray animals. Now the couple have been awarded a Daily Mirror Animal Hero Award for their Outstanding Contribution to caring for man’s best friends.John says: “This award should not be for me, it’s for Gill and Soi Dog and our supporters. Gill’s the bravest person I’ve ever met. If anybody deserves this award she does.” John and Gill, both from Leeds, got married in Phuket in Thailand in  and fell in love with the island. John says: “I had a dog, Gill had three cats. We got another dog after we got together. We did a bit of voluntary work at the local Dogs Trust kennel. Gill was the love of my le. “We were opposites in a way, she was very outgoing, I’m not particularly. We complimented each other.” They went to Phuket regularly on holiday and eventually planned to retire there, but one thing always disturbed them when they visited. John says: “When we came here on holidays we talked about trying to do something about the horrendous problem that existed with stray dogs. “In those days there were an estimated , stray dogs, the conditions of them appalling. Most of them were skeletal and covered in mange, on every street corner you’d see stray dogs.” So when they moved to the Phuket they devoted themselves to helping thousands of street dogs and cats. John says: “We decided the only humane way we could do something about this was through large-scale sterilisation.”  They met a Dutch woman who had set up a charity called the Soi Dog Foundation and in  joined forces, deciding the best long-term solution to the dog and cat problem was a mass spay and neutering programme. Every day and night they would go out tranquillising stray dogs so they could be neutered and then recover at the shelter, now named after Gill. Hundreds of thousands of dogs and cats have been neutered since, including more than % of the stray dog population in Phuket. Crucially, Gill and John were involved in drafting legislation to make it illegal to eat dog and cat meat in Thailand. John says: “We have grown a lot. Thailand now has an animal welfare bill and the consumption of dogs and cats is now illegal. “We helped put an end to the dog meat business and the trade of dogs from Thailand to Vietnam, as well as the local consumption and skinning of dogs for fur.” In , while rescuing a dog from a flooded field, Gill contracted a rare form of septicaemia and lost both her legs.  John says: “She darted this dog and had to go into a flooded field to get it because it ran off. She dragged this dog out of the field so it wouldn’t drown. “The next day she did this big party in our house, she loved to cater for our friends, but that day she said she didn’t feel well and went to bed. “By the next morning she was in agony, I took her to hospital and her legs turned blue. I was told it was unlikely she would survive andshe did she’d lose her legs and arms.” Gill survived and did not lose her arms, and soon all she wanted to do was get home to John and her animals. John says: “Three days before Christmas she told the doctors she was determined to be home with the dogs and cats.She wanted to be with friends at Christmas, she’d always do a big Christmas dinner and cooked dinner for  people from a wheelchair. She wouldn’t have any help.”Gill battled back to health, continuing to work alongside John, and together they built a huge complex of shelters to help rescued dogs. They also established an overseas adoption programme for pets.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailGuests said they would rather sleep on the street than spend a night at the UKaposs aposworst hotel chainapos, with stray hairs and stained towels found inside some rooms.Britannia Hotels have been ranked the UKaposs worst hotel chain for the eighth consecutive year, after guests described their venues as filthy. One customer said a hotel was a filthy hovel while another claimed it was by far the dirtiest hotel room I have ever stayed in. Consumer group Which  ranked Britannia Hotels as the worst chain in a survey of , guests as UV lights showed stained towels, broken glass and hair in toilets.With rooms costing an average of £ per night, making it one of the cheapest chains, guests gave Britannia just one star value for money. They were also previously the subject of a investigation by the consumer magazine into hotel hygiene during the first wave of the pandemic. When investigators visited the Grand Burstin Hotel in Folkstone in the summer they found stray hairs and stained towels in the room they had booked. Further tests indicated that surfaces had not been thoroughly cleaned between stays despite the fact the hotel had advertised a system of enhanced cleaning.At the time, the chain apologised for the lapse in protocol and said in a statement it was totally committed to providing a safe environment for visitors but accept there is more to do. However the companyaposs apology could not satisfy consumer choice website Which . Rory Boland, editor of magazine Which  Travel, said: “It appears that not even a global pandemic could force Britannia to clean up its act. “At best, it’s drab and dated, and at worst it’s downright filthy – and after eight years at the bottom of our survey, our message is loud and clear: avoid these hotels. “While Premier Inn remains a firm favourite, it’s clear that this year, UK hotels have become more than just a place to lay your head, but a destination in themselves.  “With fewer of us travelling abroad this year, our survey shows that when it comes to holidaying at home, we’re quite happy to pay more for a little luxury.” Kent Live reporter John James John James checked into a room at the Grand Burstin to see whether the hotelaposs reputation was deserved. The hotel has struggled with poor reviews for years and holds only two and a half stars on TripAdvisor. It has more than , Terrible reviews, many of them alarmingly recent. One woman wrote of her stay: What a terrible shame such a hotel still exists.  Would never stay here again and it isn’t that it’s a bargain price, it’s that price because it’s so bad. Do yourself a favour and stay where. Another wrote: The building is run down, stinks of cigarettes and booze. The interior is disgusting and our bed had pubic hair all over quite visibly. And one man swore to go to great s to never visit again. He said: Personally, couldnapost wait to leave this place and wonapost ever be back there again as I would rather sleep on the street.  Kent Live reporter John James on his stay at the Grand Burstin With such a glittering reputation, I was beginning to wonder what Iaposd let myself in for. I arrived into the Grand Burstin at around pm as the day was winding down. My first impression of the great white building that loomed above me was one of resignation. It was filthy on the outside, covered in green and brown dirt from who knows what decade. Things werenapost to improve when I ventured inside. Naively, I had assumed the hotel would be relatively quiet, considering it was a weekday. No such luck, it was packed to the rafters and the check in queue stretched around the dated foyer. As I sweated at the back of the interminable line, I did a quick headcount to see who was wearing masks.  Not only were barely any customers wearing them, many staff also had gone without. Itaposs not a requirement by law to wear them in hotels but I was still surprised. Things got worse when I reached the till and was informed Iaposd have to pay £ for the luxury of leaving my car in their car park. The sheer front of it would make a bargain flight provider blush. It was a scrum for the lts and I saw multiple family units cramming themselves into them. Disheartened, I trudged up the stairs to the fth floor to see what a double room at the Grand Burstin looks like. The TV was on when I entered the room and the view out of the window wasnapost exactly inspiring. The bedroom suffered from the worn out aesthetic of the rest of the hotel but I suppose it would look a little oddit didnapost.  Of far greater concern was the meal that came with my £ room, a sloppy plate of steak pie that managed to be greasy and dry at the same time. I stirred the tepid dish for a few seconds and trudged into the bar for a socially distanced drink. Once the bingo came on, I knew it was time for bed. I awoke with the sun light streaming in through the curtains. Iaposd deliberately left them open so as to beat the breakfast buffet rush - not that I was particularly excited for the food on show. True to Grand Burstin form, the breakfast was disappointing and actually quite meagre.

After a four-day trial, a jury of eight men and four women last Thursday found her not guilty of knowingly having sex with an underage boy. It took them just one hour to reach the verdict. Ms Vincent has since spoken to reporters about the incident and the trial, saying the last two years have been the hardest years of her le, she is not a bad mum and she has been unfairly targeted by online trolls.  In a post to her , Instagram followers, Ms Vincent wrote: Are you people actually that sad. People getting paid to spread c*** about me and Iaposm so bored now of hearing it.If it was the other way around it would be dferent. I wasnapost the one lying for a bloody start. For one Iaposm not denying what I did was my best choice butthe guy didnapost lie to me I wouldnapost be in this situation with silly gullible people around the world having their two pence peace put in. [sic] She added: Iaposm not guilty of what Iaposve got accused of and Iaposm really tired and bored of you stupid people judging me on my le and actually trying to roll me about it. If only you knew the HALF of it about what happened that night and the information on the liar that accused me you wouldnapost be so judgemental. Would love to put a few points out there that would change alot of your thoughts but Iaposm gunna keep letting you sad, sad people keep making money out of story which isnapost even true and a story which half of it is bulls***. Ms Vincent also hit out at silly journalists and dull readers as she thanked her family and other supporters for sticking by her, and encouraged people to share her post. After she was found not guilty, Ms Vincent posted a Facebook photo showing her celebrating outside court.  She wrote that it had been the hardest two years of my le. Ms Vincent told the Sun previously that she feels embarrassed and she wants to move on with her le. She said: This has wrecked my le. It’s also wrecked any chance I would have had of a career. I’m too embarrassed now to do anything. I feel hot-headed and emotional. “I just want to put all my energy now into my children and look after them.  Ms Vincent was cleared after late evidence emerged in the trial about the boy giving a  date of birth on his Facebook profile. The boy was recalled to the witness box, where he told the court he entered the wrong birth date, in the year , after he was given a new phone a week before his th birthday. He said he chose a  date of birth due to Facebookaposs minimum age requirement of . But he denied telling Ms Vincent that he was . He told the court: I definitely did not tell her I was  going on . Ms Vincent had told jurors: Iaposm sure he told me he was  and I felt he looked much older.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailRonnie the black Cayuga duck was unable to walk after a fox attack left him with two ­broken ribs and spine damage. Things looked so bad that owner Susannah Lovegrove, who pulled him from the fox’s jaws, was told it might be kinder to put him down. But after losing Ronnie’s brother Reggie and mate Cagney in the attack, Susannah was desperate to save him. She says: “I hatched him and his brother Reggie under a hen. “They grew up quite naughty ducks, chasing the other chickens and the dog. So we got them some wives. “I was totally devastated when Reggie and one of the girls were killed in the fox attack, so I was determined to save Ronnie in any way I could. “After the attack in June, I did think it’d be a case of having him put to sleep, which was heart-breaking. But we wanted to give him every chance.” Her determination saved Ronnie’s le. She says: “The vet agreed to give it a couple days to see what happened.  “Thankfully some feeling did come back in his legs and feet and so we agreed to give him pain relief and get him some physio.” Susannah, who lives with husband Giles and three children in Oxfordshire, built Ronnie a wheelchair to support and protect him while he learned to walk again. Now he is recovering well and even has his own yoga mat for his daily exercise routine. The three-year-old duck has won a Daily Mirror Animal Hero Special Recognition Award for his bravery.  Susannah says: “We do daily ­exercises on his yoga mat, he has daily swimming sessions in the bath, and he has massage on his feet and legs to help nerve repair. “I even built him his own set of wheels, it’s basically a sling on wheels, which you can push around. It simulates the treadmill, and also gives him support when he is eating, washing and preening himself. It also gives him social time with the other ducks without them trampling on him.” Before the attack, cheeky Ronnie used to chase the family dog Willow and stick his head through the cat flap to taunt her. But now that injured Ronnie sleeps indoors at night the pair have become firm friends, and even snuggle up together in the kitchen.  “Willow seems to have accepted Ronnie and is very good with him, allowing him to share her bed and she even lets him have a little beak nuzzle,” Susannah says. “I think she knows he can’t chase her any more, so she can relax!” Due to his complex needs, Susannah has had to take Ronnie with her on trips as far away as Cornwall and Bedfordshire.

If you are not sick of data by now, then the ZOE Covid Symptom Study app presents its daily data from experts at health science company ZOE and Kingaposs College London, in a handy new dashboard. It shows the prevalence rate - cases per , of the population - of coronavirus for every area in England as well as the rate among people aged  and above. In a glimmer of hope, it shows only five subregions which are in Tier  and where the case rate is rising. This includes the county of Suffolk in the East of England, and in the South East, the combined subregion of Reading, Wokingham, Bracknell Forest, Windsor and Maidenhead and West Berkshire has seen cases rise. Meanwhile, in the South West region, the apossubregionapos of Wiltshire and Swindon has also seen cases rise. And in the North West, the apossubregionapos of Warrington and Cheshire has also seen cases increase. If these places continue to see cases rise they could enter the dreaded Tier  next week when the tiers are set to be reviewed. The ZOE Covid Symptom Study report is presented to the Government each day. The latest report shows that the majority of England has seen cases per , of the population fall or remain the same. But it is bad news for the Warwickshire, Coventry and Solihull subregion in the West Midlands region, as they sit in the toughest Tier  and are seeing cases rise - meaning they may be stuck there for a while yet. And in Yorkshire, in the Humber, cases have also increased in the Tier  area. Iaposm confident that Zoeaposs app data really is the most up-to-date picture we have, he said. The latest survey figures were based on data from , swab tests done between November  to . Boris Johnsonaposs toughened  Tiers lockdown system will be reviewed every two weeks. As it was implemented on December , this means Wednesday next week will be the date of the first review.  Decisions will be made based on the latest case rate data, how much capacity the NHS has and what advice and recommendations are made by local directors of public health. Any changes will come into effect on December , after a decision is made at a Cabinet committee. The plan is to have the tiers system brought back before Parliamen on January , by which time it will have been reviewed four times. Vaccine details emerging It comes as Downing Street today confirmed more details of who will be first in line to get the vaccine when the first doses are delivered tomorrow. Alongside the those already revealed to be in line for doses, No  has confirmed that people being discharged from hospital after treatment will also be eligible for the vaccine - so long as they meet one of the other criteria. The first priority groups for hospitals will be people over , those who work in care homes or on the front lines of the NHS.  Care home residents are also in the first batch of the priority list but roll-out to them has been delayed because the approval to break up doses of the vaccine for delivery to inidual homes was not confirmed until today. A Downing Street spokesperson said: The NHS set out over the weekend that we have , doses available. The first of the vaccine will go to people over  alongside care home workers and frontline NHS workers. They have also set out that a small number of NHS primary care networks will begin delivering the vaccine from next week, the week beginning the th. They also confirmed that hospitals will be inviting people who already have out patients appointmentsthey meet the criteria - as will people who are leaving the hospital after treatment. The others will join throughout December and the coming months, they added. Asked about when care homes will begin to recieve doses, they added: The process of delivering care home will begin shortly...I donapost have a date. Care homes are rightly at the top of the list so they will be prioritised. Downing Street dismissed the prospect of NHS vaccination cards becoming a form of “immunity passport” to allow people who have received the jab to enjoy extra freedoms. “We have been clear that there are no plans to introduce immunity passports,” the Prime Minister’s official spokesperson said. “The cards … are NHS reminder cards that prompt people to get the second dose that they need. “That’s a well-established practice in the NHS to offer people cards to remind them of their next appointment.” The Government said it expects “the majority” of vulnerable people will be vaccinated in January and February.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn assassination of a top Iranian nuclear scientist was done by an “articial intelligence” camera zooming in on him and a machine gun opening fire, severing his spine. The “AI hit” on Tehranaposs nuke mastermind Mohsen Fakhrizadeh took  bullets and happened as the camera focused on him, triggering the pick-up mounted rle soon after. Chilling further details of the “death by remote” operation – probably launched by Israelaposs feared Mossad intelligence agency- only emerged today. As the top man behind Iranaposs top secret nuclear programme the scientist was at the very top of Tel Avivaposs hit list, as many other Iranian nuclear boffins have been. It is now believed the machine gun, mounted on a pick-up truck  yards from where his car had stopped on the way home was equipped with a satellite controlled smart system. Tasnim, a semi-official agency, quoted Ali Fadavi, the deputy commander of Iranaposs Revolutionary Guards, as saying: No terrorists were present on the ground...Martyr Fakhrizadeh was driving when a weapon, using an advanced camera, zoomed in on him. The machine gun was placed on a pick-up truck and was controlled by a satellite. Soon after the November  killing the pick-up truck was blown up, again apparently by remote, as the killers destroyed evidence.  The owner of the vehicle had fled Iran weeks before, leaving the kill-team to plant it at a spot on the scientistaposs route to his home. Israel has neither confirmed nor denied responsibility for the killing, but in the past has acknowledged pursuing covert intelligence-gathering operations against Iranian nuclear projects.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe world’s largest iceberg is on a collision course with South Georgia, putting seals, penguins and other wildle at risk, scientists have warned. The ice sheet – roughly the size of Devon – is being monitored as it creeps towards the British Overseas Territory in the South Atlantic. Biologists sayit crashes into the island it will cause major environmental damage to the wildle haven, a breeding ground for more than a million animals. Dr Adam Fleming, of the British Antarctic Survey, said: “The next two to three weeks are going to be key in deciding whether the berg will hit South Georgia or narrowly miss it.” Iceberg Aa broke off from Antarctica in  and has since drted for more than , miles. It covers , sq miles and is about  miles long. An RAF aircraft photographed the iceberg as it drted through the South Atlantic. Photos reveal multiple cracks and fissures, and what appear to be tunnels under the waterline.The government of South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands is “keeping a close eye” on the iceberg. But the concern is that it could ground on shallower waters around the island. Due to the huge volume of much colder, fresh water from the iceberg, micro algae and plankton would struggle to thrive, in turn affecting species such as krill, which rely on plankton for food, which would then impact penguins and seals.

story: A wonderful solo goal from Paul McGowan earned Dundee their first win in four matches as they edged past Arbroath at Dens Park.The Dark Blues had to work for their second Championship win of the season with both goalkeepers pulling off impressive saves throughout.McGowan#s th minute strike was the dference between the sides with the Red Lichties still awaiting their first victory of the campaign.There was one change in the Dark Blues starting XI with striker Danny Mullen ing after self-isolation and replacing Jonathan Afolabi who hadn#t recovered from a hamstring complaint.Jack Hamilton remained in goal with Adam Legzdins still out and faced brother Colin in the Lichties line-up that also included former Dee Bobby Linn among four changes from the cup defeat to Dunfermline.On the bench for Dick Campbell#s side was Dens hero Rab Douglas at the age of .After a minute#s silence in memory of Dundee league winner Bobby Wishart who sadly passed away this week, the match started in the nippy sunshine.The Dark Blues had the ball in the net after just seven minutes but Mullen had strayed offside before the visitors showed their threat.First a dangerous Linn cross flashed across the six-yard box, evading everyone before Michael Ruth ran in on goal on  minutes.The wide man cut inside Jordan Marshall and looked certain to score only to see his effort blocked by Hamilton in the tremendous save prevented a first senior goal for Max Anderson on  minutes.McGowan was running the show for the Dark Blues in the opening half and got his rewards with the opening goal on  minutes.The experienced midfielder picked the ball up in the middle of the park and drove at the Arbroath defence before pinging a shot from  yards in off the post with the outside of his foot.It was an excellent strike and it looked like Dundee might get the chance for a second as Tam O#Brien handled in the area but the ref waved play on.Shortly after the restart the home side were on the attack again as Elliott saw a wayward cross flick off Gaston#s crossbar.On  minutes, Mullen sent a curling effort wide of the far post before Dale Hilson had a golden chance to equalise.The former Dundee United forward had a clear look at goal but smashed the shot well over the bar under pressure from Liam Fontaine.Minutes later the Red Lichties went even closer as Jason Thomson met a Michael McKenna header only for Hamilton to pull off a great save to keep the home side#s lead.The quality in the match faded as the second half progressed with Dundee unable to revive their first-half performance.They title: dundee boss james mcpake says it took a special goal to prevent in form arbroath keeper derek gaston causing the dark blues a nightmare
story: Dundee boss James McPake says it took “a special goal” to get the better of Derek Gaston as the Arbroath keeper threatened to make it a “nightmare” afternoon for the Dark Blues.On the back of three straight defeats, the Dens Park club were in need of three points to get their Championship campaign up and running.And McPake was delighted with his team’s first-half performance as they saw off the Red Lichties - at Dens Park with Paul McGowan’s wonderful strike capping an impressive opening  minutes.Though he felt they should have been further in front by the break with Gaston pulling off top saves to deny Christie Elliott and Max Anderson.McPake said: “I’m the first to criticise my team when we’re not at it but the only criticism I had of that first half was that we’re not - up.“We had the chances to put the game to bed and make it more comfortable but credit to Gaston in the Arbroath goal.“He made great saves but we could have been more ruthless in front of goal.“We also should have had a stonewall penalty .“We defended our box really well in the second half which I was pleased about.“I know Jack Hamilton made a great save and I’m delighted for him but sometimes you need that.“Liam Fontaine and Lee Ashcroft both defended our box really well because Arbroath threw everything at us.“We stood firm and I’m delighted for the players, they deserved that.“It was a great three points for us against a really stuffy team. I do wish we had made it more comfortable, though.”Attacking midfielder McGowan was at the heart of everything good about the Dark Blues in the opening half and topped the performance with a goal of the season contender.Having run with the ball from the middle of the park, McGowan fired in from  yards with his outside of the foot shot clipping the post on its way into the net.“McGowan was fantastic, all our chances were coming through him and his goal was fantastic,” said McPake.“It reminded me of a similar goal he scored against United with the outside of his boot – he seems to hit it better with that. title: revealed poorest pupils in tayside and fife attempting less subjects compared to five years ago
story: The poorest pupils in Tayside and Fe are attempting less subjects at school compared to five years ago, new data has revealed.Scottish Government data reveals the average S pupil in in Dundee enrolled in . subjects in August – almost an entire subject less than in .Subject choice has been limited for pupils across Scotland since the inception of the Curriculum for Excellence in , according to the Scottish Conservatives who obtained the data using freedom of information legislation.The statistics are based on SQA data across all SCQF levels and include both resulted and incomplete entries in subject areas including Highers, National qualications and Skills for Work courses.Braeview Academy, which has some of the city’s poorest students, has an average of . subjects – known as entries – being sat this year.The school’s figures are among the lowest in the whole of Scotland.Grove Academy pupils, in comparison, were registered for four subjects in August.Angus youngsters are also taking less subjects than they were five years ago. Pupils were sitting roughly . subjects in , compared with . in August.On a school level, fth year pupils at Montrose Academy enrolled in an average of . subjects and Arbroath Academy and Forfar and Academy had ., compared to Monieth High School which had ..Labour Holyrood candidate and education specialist Barry Black said pupils in Dundee and Angus had were being given less opportunities than the rest of their Scottish peers.He said: “These figures show that subject choice in Dundee and Angus is reducing, and that young people in our region have fewer opportunities in S than in other parts of the country.”The Glasgow University researcher said the figures show a “signicant” reduction in subject entries since the new Higher qualications were introduced in .Changes were made to the qualications to put them in line with National s and s, which replaced Standard Grades.Mr Black added: “Issues with a narrowing curriculum have been known for some time, and it requires urgent action to recty before more young people lose out on opportunities that would have previously been available to them.”Pupils at Fe’s Lochgelly High School and Levenmouth Academy, where the majority of pupils are in the most deprived quintiles, were typically taking . and . subjects each.Bell Baxter High School, in Cupar, and Madras College, St Andrews, had an average . and  entries respectively in August.Subject numbers have declined across the kingdom from . in  to . in .Pupils at Perth Grammar School, however, are taking more subjects this year than they were in .Despite the increase, pupils still have less entries than their peers in Perth and Kinross with . subjects per S pupil.Comparatively, Perth High School pupils have almost a subject more with .. The local authority average has also dropped from . in  to ..Jamie Greene, Scottish Conservatives shadow education secretary said: “Under the SNP, subject choices continues to reduce year on year and we know that it will be pupils from poorer backgrounds suffering the most.“Scottish pupils are being denied opportunities to study subjects they want. title: aberdeen cinema shuts door for remainder of festive period
story: An Aberdeen cinema will remain shut during the festive season.Belmont Filmhouse, located on Belmont Street, has announced it will temporarily shut its doors during the holiday period after the current pandemic has made #short-term planning incredibly challenging#.Every year, the venue offers a lineup of Christmas films for the public to enjoy, but have decided to cancel plans due to rising number of Covid- cases.This year#s featured screenings would have included Home Alone, Muppets Christmas Carol and It’s A Wonderful Le,A statement by the cinema said: #After much thought, we have made the decision not to re-open Belmont Filmhouse over the festive period#While we would have loved nothing more than to switch the lights back on at Belmont Filmhouse, illuminating our little stretch of Belmont Street, and welcome you in to enjoy the magic of film, the ongoing public health environment locally has made short-term planning incredibly challenging and we’ve now reached a point where we can no longer delay a decision.#While we’re confident in the Covid- precautions in place in our cinema, we’re also keenly aware of staff and customers safety and well-being and their need for certainty over Christmas.#The statement goes on the emphasise the venue will reopen in  as soon as management is able to do so.It added: #If conditions allow that in January, all the better. title: first year pupils at ellon academy told to stay at home for further two days after positive coronavirus case
story: All S students at a north-east academy have been told to stay at home for two more days after a positive Covid- case was detected.It comes after parents from the school were informed of the new case on Sunday night and were told to keep their first-year pupils at home today as a precaution.Ellon Academy students were told they needed to wait for a call from Test and Protect to establishthey had been a close contact of the positive case.In a statement posted online tonight, the school updated parents and carers that all S students will have to stay home on Tuesdayand Wednesday in order to allow Test and Protect officials to carry out their work.It read: #Dear parents and carers, thank you for your continued patience in these circumstances, and to all S parents for your support and understanding.#To allow Test and Protect to continue with their investigation to identy the potential close contacts of the new Covid- case , we are asking that all S pupils remain at home on Tuesday, December  and Wednesday, December  to give our NHS colleagues time to conclude this process.#We will be back in touchthere is any change to this scenario. S pupils working at home over the next two days are asked to log onto Google Classroom to access their subjects from home.#All additional cleaning has been actioned and pupils and staff are frequently reminded of our Covid mitigations and our risk assessment.#Please be assured that all actions taken are based on advice and liaison with the health protection team for the safety and wellbeing of everyone concerned.
